ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Restructuring of thought about Africa and its relationship with the rest of the world. Uncovering truths about colonial histories. Grappling with independence and the way forward. Reading a wealth of incredible scholarship for and done by Africans.
This course allowed me further my ability to analyze and critique work.

I developed insight into how Africa is discussed in the western world and how all of this is affected by colonization. I improved my textual annotation skills as well as speaking skills in our seminar discussions.

it's an incredible course that really taught me skills that I expected a Yale education to give me. I learned to learn about not only Africa but anything with an open mind and considering different perspectives in analysing the world. it was very eye-opening. I learn to free myself of stigmas in understanding the world and others. The skills go beyond understanding just Africa.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths- Great conversation in class, Leslie is absolutely wonderful, will seriously cause you change the way you think about the world (especially if you are a citizen of the global north)

Weaknesses- could benefit from meeting twice a week rather than once

This class was really engagingthe environment was growth oriented and not intimidating. Assignments all very reasonable. I would like a little more specificity in the curriculum though. It is very broad and I wouldve liked to avoid generalizing to the whole continent.
Very conducive for learning; I loved how we broke up in small groups to discuss questions/themes

Strengths: very understanding and informative learning environment, which is definitely facilitated by the professor and classmates.

Weaknesses: I had difficulty finishing all the readings each week.

I think it is a very engaging course with cool readings and a supportive class environment. The skills you gain are invaluable and everyone should learn them. it's a very chill course. sometimes it could be a little more stimulating but overall great course. take it with the goal of learning amazing flexibility skills and if you want a relatively chill class

Strengths: Discussions were lively, readings were chosen well, Leslie is a tremendous professor, content is really interesting, assignments are interesting and not over-bearing

Weaknesses: None

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely!!! This course is really incredible, and Leslie is a prof you absolutely want to take a class with in your time at Yale. My understanding of the world has been seriously expanded

Yes! Prof. Gross-Wyrtzen is very knowledgeable and inclusive and the class is very little work for the amount of intellectual payoff. The final project is a good time to explore whichever part of the wide ranging course interests you most!
Yes, this course is very engaging and fun for students of all backgrounds.
Yes, definitely. Especially if you havent taken anything under ANTH or AFST before.

YES! This is a fantastic course. You get to think about Africa's relationship to the Western world at a level much deeper than most people have experience with. You read a lot of both foundational and cutting-edge work in postcolonial theory and get to discuss them in a warm but intellectually vibrant environment. Leslie is a great professor who will make you think about things in a way and with a depth you never have before. If you are even remotely interested in African studies, postcolonial studies, migration, global affairs, etc., this class is a must-take.
